pros: Salary, but, if you want time off you'll need to work extra on the days you are working so you won't fall behind (no overtime). The direct team of specialists is supportive and kind. A lot of people end up moving up career wise at YV, but there isn't much actual room for growth... about 5 positions in management are on rotation regularly due to turnover. You are eligible for benefits, but with the pay being about 3k each month before benefits are taken out... You get an additional 80 for your cell phone and your mileage is paid, but depends on miles and where you go..
cons: Pay was very low. No overtime pay and if you work a holiday you will get an additional day off later, but, to take days off, you have to do extra work on your working days so you do not fall behind. Tried to express our needs as a team and was always just referred to HR who stated there was nothing they could do, and encouraged to provide feedback on annual surveys and stay interviews. They made sure to skip some of our stay interviews though.. They promised us to increase our pay, but, 6 months later, still nothing. Super understaffed and low retention. No hazard pay during the pandemic, made decisions on how specialists will conduct in-home sessions at peak breakout periods without talking to them about it. Client will most likely have your personal phone number, as you do not get a work phone. You go to clients homes and transport them in your own car. You will lack privacy in that regard. Annual salary is an additional approximate 100 a month. You cannot regularly cash out unused vacation/sick time.

review_title: No Work/Life Balance, Company is Very Anti Union/Anti Worker
pros:
- Pay is good for a social work position
- Fulfilling work
cons:
- The company is incredibly anti union. When work got out that workers were trying to unionize, instead of trying to determine why, the company doubled down on an anti union campaign, spreading blatant anti-union information (some of which was downright untrue). They spread an environment of fear, which was confusing since the company touts wanting to support its employees. And what's worse, our two biggest "customers" (DCF and DMH) are both unionized and workers from both organizations have highlighted how much the working conditions have improved since they unionized. 
- There is literally no work life balance. Your supervisors will encourage you to maintain it but we are still expected to get everything in on time, see all of our kids, drive to and from and attend all of our meetings. It's entirely unsustainable. The turnover is absolutely absurd. I've been here less than 6 months and I've already seen 5 people from just my office leave for other opportunities because of the aforementioned issue.
- Case loads can be absurd. We can carry up to 10 young adults in Life Set and, if you're lucky, you may only need to see them once a week but more likely than not, you'll be seeing at least half of them twice a week, meaning you somehow need to have 15 sessions a week, get your documentation and treatment plans done, attend all necessary meetings and trainings and avoid working over 40 hours a week. 
- There is not a lot of clinical skills training. They will train you how to use our intervention resource to find an intervention to use with your client but there is not training on how to implement the intervention with fidelity. The resource offers step by step instructions but for those who come from a non-clinical background, that often is not enough.
- Our clinical judgement is often ignored. We are told to put things into our treatment plans or do things with clients that we often know are going to be triggering or unsuccessful but we are required to do so. It makes building rapport and maintaining engagement that much more difficult. 
- When it comes to diversity and inclusion, Youth Villages may talk the talk but they do not walk the walk. Upper management is overwhelming white folks, there has been an ongoing struggle to get paperwork updated to reflect the plethora of pronouns and gender identities that exist and the gate keeping that occurs around what can and cannot be discussed during "culture crews" is astonishing. 
- Management encourages you to bring your concerns to them but nothing gets done about them. Some managers even go as far as to say that they used to bring the same feedback to their supervisors when they were on the ground staff. And yet, nothing has been done to change any of these concerns despite their repeated occurrence.

cons: It is difficult not to become attached to the youth as many of them don't have close family relationships. It is understandable that this is not encouraged. job_title: Family Intervention Specialist in Portland, OR
pros: Helping kids and their families and you get good health insurance.
cons: Company doesn’t care about your well being. Company focuses on quantity over quality of work. If you work here you will be taken advantage of. I’ve spent almost the past two years here and have seen almost everyone leave. There are so many things that make this place a place you don’t want to work; no work life balance, always increasing caseload (when I was hired I was told 4 cases was maximum and now the normal is 5-6 cases), youth villages prides itself on providing in home services to youth and families however the current expectation is that of the required 3 sessions a week per client only one session needs to be in person thus making it possible to carry extra cases…, however if a family is at high risk or requests in person you are expected to do all sessions in person (intercept program is level D = so all cases are technically high risk), so basically you end up working at least 50 hours a week and not to mention the paperwork, some cases are super heavy with case management which is difficult to constantly stay on top of when you’re having to drive all the way from Hillsboro, Gresham, lake Oswego, Milwaukee, north Portland, St. Helens, rhodendrun, sandy, se Portland, Ne Portland, sw Portland, nw Portland, forest grove, Estacada, etc, basically they tell you that that your cases will be around where you live so your driving isn’t terrible and sadly that’s never the case. Taking vacation is also difficult because your team is expected to carry your caseload and that’s tough because you know they are also working overtime and are exhausted. The mileage pay is trash. You are also expected to have full coverage car insurance even though we don’t ever drive clients. You will be expected to work when asked and cover on call weekends if people bail or leave because they are over working there. If you’re trying to get experience in the social work field, go work somewhere else, this place is headed in a very bad direction and it’s so hard to support your families if your company doesn’t support you as an employee as well as sincerely care about each and every family that they work with. I would say that the hardest past about the job is standing up for the families, advocating for their needs and then being shut down by youth villages and not receiving any support. Don’t waste your time, take your skills elsewhere and do the same job but be supported by your employer and respected by your employer because from my experience you won’t get that at youth villages (maybe in the beginning but it doesn’t last). Lastly, being on call isn’t always great because if there is a crisis and you need to check in with the on call supervisor there’s a solid chance they won’t pick up - this has happened many times.

review_title: Change the world, one child at a time.
job_title: Foster Care Counselor in Knoxville, TN
pros:
When you come to work at Youth Villages you join an elite team of individuals from every walk of life, determined to make the lives of the youth in our city, your city, and the nation better. The word "altruism" defines us and there are no limits to what can be achieved when people stand together to help one another help the community. From the office manager to the executive director, every person that works at Youth Villages is saving lives everyday. We work with teens all the way down to itty bitty babies with the diligence and fervor and the heart necessary to help children and families heal, reunite, and to move onward and upward.

This job is a lifestyle more than a job and if you are looking to make a difference in your community and have the right qualifications, then this is the place for you. The case loads are lighter than similar jobs working for the state and you could not hope to find a more loving, fun bunch of people to work with.
cons: Be prepared for a lot of learning and organization. This is all paid for and provided by Youth Villages but I would want anyone coming into this job to know this so that they can be prepared. It's not really a "con" so to speak since it is a part of every job. As a former college professor I just wanted to let you know what's coming.

review_title: The perfect job if you have a passion for helping others & if you pay attention to self-care
job_title: Family Intervention Specialist in Knoxville, TN
pros: Working at YV has been such a joy in my life! Being on the frontline and having a direct impact on the lives of the families we serve is incredibly fulfilling. Each day is different and we get to make our own schedules. We are provided with laptops to do documentation in the field which is so helpful and makes admission sessions more efficient. We are reimbursed for gas expenses and cell phone expenses. Leadership is phenomenal- my supervisor has been a key player in my positive experience at YV. We have weekly one-on-one development meetings and she is always there if i have a question, concern or if I need emotional support. There are so many trainings that are offered for free to add to your professional development.
cons: The work we do can be emotionally exhausting. Work/life balance can be a struggle. If you take care of yourself, prioritize, and manage time in a productive way, it IS possible! Also, the amount of time spent driving can take its toll. Get creative- I listen to audiobooks or new music to make the drive feel shorter. I’ve found that the cons I’ve experienced at this job can be fixed on a personal level. If I️ take responsibility, practice self-care and communicate with my supervisor, I stay on top of my tasks and can effectively handle the emotional struggles that come and go.

Most people who stay have no time for a life outside of work (these people are usually single, living alone in Durham/Raleigh, don't have kids, straight out of college).

Working at Youth Villages, I felt as though I made a major difference in countless families lives and gave them resources and skills to continue success.
cons: The agency continues to recommend that all youth in their In Home Services remain in the home, even when the youth is in need of a higher level of care.  They have all employees document that the youth is "at risk of removal from the home" even when they are not, and refuse to recommend residential treatment, no matter what circumstances.    Attempting to advocate for ethical concerns, immediately get shut down by leadership and clinical consultants.  Advocating either gets you a "burn out assessment" or a statement that you should just sit down and be quiet.  If you are not leadership staff, it is presented as though your opinion is irrelevant.  Leadership staff has zero compassion for their employees and is continuously shown to make statements to "suck it up" when employees voice concerns or questions about unrealistic job expectations or requests.

This is a money making scene run by a bunch of monkies in suits. There is no organization and kids receive little to no treatment. Their orientation is propaganda that attempts to get you to believe that what they are doing is therapy. It's not. They teach buzz words to developmentally delayed and traumatized children. It's a holding cell with no therapeutic value.
cons: Everything about this place is a con. It's unsafe, they pay poorly with unfair benefits packages. They value their employees little. They will lie to you every chance they get. Just run. Run as fast as you can.

-management was hard to deal with. If you earn vacation time/sick time you need to plan months in advance. There is absolutely no times you can call out sick. 

-I worked countless 24 hour shifts (if an er trip is needed a TC gets thrown in with no info about the patient & no shift relief.)you're expected to be back into work 3 hours after a 24 hour shift. 

-management would ask you to spend personal money. (Activities or if a patient loses something and we need to replace it) 

-total disregard by management. my belongings got stollen and MOD refused to come across campus because it was dark. 

-I will never unsee the things I saw at GL. self harm and violence etc. 

-there was a brawl on campus and no one could tell me what to do when it happens again.

review_title: YV is the Force for Families
pros: Youth Villages always works in the best interest of the children and families they serve.  The staff have what it takes to help families be successful.  Its a tough job being on call 24/7 but it works.  Seeing a family in crisis and helping guide them through it is what really matters.  There is always a sense of team collaberation and willingness to brainstorm interventions needed to help families.  Staff have the opportiunity to be promoted within which ensures each member of leadership, managers, directors and clinical consultants, even the CEO has been in the front lines doing the clinical work that is talked about, that means the most to me.  I believe in the mission and values that YV represents.
cons: In the beginning, finding that work life balance can be tricky.  YV offers a "flexible schedule" which is great, with the realization that some days and weeks will be longer than others.  Once employees master the balance this type of schedule can be very rewarding.  Training does take a while, the learning curve for me was about 3 months to really learn and understand the treatment model, but once I did I really liked using it.

pros: This is a great place to work right out of college and where you can gain some experience working with challenging populations, the mental health system, and where you get a lot of support from peers and supervisors. If you don't know something, someone is usually always available to support and advise. It is also a great community of professionals who become a sort of work family. The job itself is rewarding. There are a lot of opportunities for training and to get reimbursed for outside training if needed.
cons: The job is challenging and demands long hours. Sometimes the job duties go beyond the scope of a 40 hour a week job, which is both personally and financially burdensome. The job exposes professionals to physically aggressive clients which at times is counter-productive to the role of a therapist and to the success of therapy. The health insurance is not great. As an agency that requires its staff to be in top shape this is very unfortunate.

review_title: Hardest job I have ever loved
pros: In my experience leadership are very supportive toward staff. Every supervisor I have had since joining YV has treated me with respect and as a peer rather than as a subordinate. They have encouraged my development as a clinician and as a leader. I feel valued and heard more now than in any prior professional setting. I appreciate the way the company invests in staff success. For example, I was able to complete my second Master's degree through the tuition reimbursement offered by Youth Villages. I am currently seeking licensure with support from YV.  The multi-level clinical supervision structure ensures strong accountability and enables staff to serve youth and families with confidence. I appreciate Youth Villages' mission and values and how those are reflected in the work that we do daily. Helping youth and families to live successfully can be challenging but also quite rewarding.
cons: The work we do is very demanding with regard to time and energy. Work life balance is definitely a challenge in this field. The rewards don't necessarily come in the form of financial compensation. Working in community based programs has put a lot of miles on my vehicles.

pros:
If you are looking for a job right out of college, this would be good to do for one year. Nothing more.

Do not work here if you are a seasoned professional.
cons:
Toxic Leadership: Youth Villages hires “yes” men/women for leadership- people who don’t ask questions and are eager to please. If you ask questions, they will call you a bully to your face and ask you to stop wanting to understand & instead, to do what is asked of you (hilarious!!). Even at the highest leadership levels, they are not allowed to be deeply curious people who ask questions. If you are someone who has a rapacious desire to understand and learn, this is not the place for you. They are threatened by intelligent people. If you can’t be controlled, they don’t want you to stick around. 

Notice the Youth Villages replies on this page — they are generic & condescending (“we make sure candidates know the demands of the job” in response to a person who listed a lack of response from anyone above them for their safety or after being assaulted). 

Youth Villages calls abused children & dysfunctional families “customers.” Semantics matters. Please stop calling them customers. The insurance provider is the customer. 

Youth Villages (Nashville) needs a full turnover of leadership — they will not be able to retain their best people until they get rid of the prideful & insecure leaders who quiver at questions.

job_title: B2B Sales Consultant in Melville, NY
pros: salary, work from home is ok
cons: no fun makes me sad

job_title: Mental Health Therapist in Biloxi, MS
pros: salary is okay, but more is needed considering all the running around
cons: too much running and no home-life balance

pros: Mileage, yearly bonuses, PTO, sick days
cons: No work life balance, supervisors don't care

pros: not many pros other that it's a job
cons:
The people are immature, the leadership is uncooperative, and anyone will throw you under the bus in order to get a promotion. If you expect to move up, you have to be involved in the cliques of management that form, otherwise dont expect to be acknowledged unless someone needs you to come in to do extra work. The people with degrees, dont even get paid real overtime - while those in positions that dont require a degree, can easily make a $1000 paycheck bi-weekley because they're allowed to have unlimited amounts of overtime pay. 
The children here do have their share of issues, but the focus isnt on their treatment process - the company is more concerned about letting these children have too much fun, and they in turn feel entitled to a host of things.
Most of the people employed in this company either have no other options, or hate their job. The farther you work away from the kids the happier those employees are (ie. any one in a leadership position)
If the CEO could be a fly on the wall and actually see what was going on in this company there would be a complete overhaul, or either this company would be non-existent. It has the potential to be really great, but right now it's a complete mess

review_title: LifeSet Specialist - Lots of focus on kids, care nothing about employees or their families.
job_title: Transitional Living Specialist in Memphis, TN
pros: Going to Conference once a year, I enjoy working with the youth. There are not many pros to this job. One good thing is that they will hire anyone with a college degree.
cons: Poor salary, poor raises, promotion is based more on the buddy system than experience, unrealistic work expectations, horrible wear on your car, horrible work-life balance, low morale for front line staff, does not pay well but has the audacity to ask the employees to give up to 3% back to the company (they don't even give 3% raises), little room for growth, little support from upper management. Only get paid .42 cents per mile when the government rate is .55 cents, on top of having to have excessive car insurance coverage. They are hiring kids fresh out of college and paying them $12 an hour.

review_title: The worst employment experience in my life
pros: Youth Villages is very Public Relations conscience. They know how to sell the services and have the outside world feel as if it is a successful organization.
cons: Youth Villages promotes a culture in which front line staff members are considered expendable and unimportant. Management is encouraged to be highly demanding, unforgiving and at times, cruel. They value young managers who can be molded into the YV way instead of those who are experienced and effective. Their turnover rate among direct care staff is atrocious. However they seem to like it that way. They do not understand that it is these staff that will ultimately determine the success of the organization. A Fortune 500 approach will not work in Behavioral Care as they are finding out now. But most important, I now work at a facility that cares about the employees, including front-line staff. This organization monitors employee morale and does not demand what they are not willing to pay for in a fair wage. Guess what! It is a successful organization and people like working there. Youth Villages doesn't realize that being a cruel, unethical organization will not equal success in this field.

pros: Everyone who works at Youth Villages, from counselors all the way up to directors, all works extremely hard. I know there are some really negative reviews, but working in this field in general is really hard. My experience has been that generally everyone has done their best to provide the best counseling to their clients and the managers the best support to their staff. Of course, there are people here and there that aren't great, but you will find that in every company. A companies worth can't be measured by those few "bad apples." And of course, there are some days that are stressful and not as great as others. But show me a company where every single day is great and I'll be surprised. Overall, the staff and managers at Youth Villages are some of the hardest working people I've ever met. They are passionate about their clients and about helping and supporting each other. In my opinion, it's a great place to work.
cons: I wish that people wouldn't always focus on the negative. Of course there are challenges in the jobs at Youth Villages, but it is to be expected in working a job where you are trying to make positive change in the world.

review_title: Great company; still room for improvement.
job_title: Family Intervention Specialist in Paris, TN
pros:
Great pay, benefits, and mileage reimbursement. 
Great people (for the most part). 
Great ideals. 
Visionary CEO. 
Great opportunities. 
Opportunities to provide feedback and collaborate with others company wide.
Travel opportunities (for instructors, training, commuting to families, etc.).
cons:
Lots of somewhat useless training. 
Long hours (if you're not good at work/life balance). 
Families are often less than cordial and difficult to locate/get in touch with. 
Long commutes at times. 
Often long periods of waiting for things to get done such as moving reimbursement, hiring, case transfers, etc. 
Unorganized and sloppy coworkers (this is hard when cases are transferred because information isn't always communicated properly so there's a lot of guessing).

pros: I enjoyed working with the clients, the ones that actually wanted the help. I enjoyed my team of co-workers as they supported me. When I left I was told changes were being made, so hopefully changes were done to help support workers, and train management.
cons:
I was micromanaged and not trusted to do the job I have been trained to do. Supervisors was unclear with her expectations and changes them as she goes without communicating with myself or others on the team.

Supervisor was very rude and disrespectful over text and email but put on a different front in person. She never admitted when she was wrong, and made the team look bad instead of herself. 

The company expected me to pull kids out of school or work just to make sure they would meet even after the kids said they were busy. I experienced and unsafe situations and was expected to be put back in the same situation

Supervisor does not treat everyone on the team equally. She had favorites and would make excuses as to why I had different standards then other people on the team. 

The support from management was not there when I was going through a tough personal time. 

The overall environment of the office was stressful and made it not enjoyable to go into work.

job_title: Family Intervention Specialist in Worcester, MA
pros:
Flexible schedule.. if you get the right supervisor it can be manageable 
Working from home is an option and you are now provided with a lap top
cons:
The work load and expectations if the company are unrealistic. Work/life balance does not exist because you are expected to put your clients before your own family. 
When situations get tough management uses intimidation and personal attacks to get staff to comply. They focus on blaming instead of helping and supporting. 
Half of the staff that are in management are not qualified to run/lead a team never mind an office. 
The turn over rate is insane! In one month 4 staff members left .. thats one a week !! In an office of 10-12 specialists. 
When you advocate for the needs of your clients .. if is not aligned with company mission/values you are shut down completely and then you become the problem.. " you are not doing your job".
The office management barely interact with staff only when they are "non compliant"

job_title: Family Intervention Specialist in Atlanta, GA
pros:
Paid time off
Assisting families that want to be assisted
Mileage reimbursement 
Friendly staff
Free trainings
Benefits
Cell phone reimbursement
cons: Where should I️ start? The position is great for a new clinician, however, the work is case management, not therapy. The pay is entry level bachelors degree at best. You will spend 12 hours a week doing therapy and 50 hours driving, and doing paperwork, plus 4 hours a week in purposeless meetings. Paperwork is redundant. Upper management are constantly telling you what you did wrong, even though you were not even trained on how to do the paperwork. They wait for you to fail and are quick to let you know that you failed. It’s a numbers game, to appear as if YV is going above and beyond for the families they serve. The work is very rewarding, however, the unrealistic demands upper management has on staff causes low morale.

review_title: DO NOT APPLY FOR THIS JOB!
job_title: Family Intervention Specialist in Tulsa, OK
pros: Benefits, helpful coworkers, great families,
cons: No work-life balance, 40+ hours per week, working with the DHS workers, office culture

review_title: Great for job experience, bad work/life balance
pros: The work that you do with clients can be very fulfilling. Within my team, I had very supportive colleagues and a great supervisor. There was a lot of emphasis on community building activities including weekly lunches, board game breaks, etc.
cons: There is an unstated expectation that you work more than the 40 hours you're hired for. Many times I found myself working from home late in the night completing paperwork, etc because during the day you're on the road. A lot of the paperwork required monthly is very redundant. Although there are some evfforts made for counselor retention, the primary focus is on census retention. I felt like there were a lot of changes going on in the organization that we were not included on as well. This is not a good company to work for you if you have a family with children as you're often expected to put your clients first before your family obligations.

pros: My co-workers were great and very supportive. We were our own little family/support team. I was blessed with lifetime friends. Knowing I had a part in improving multiple children's lives is something I'll carry with me forever.
cons: Upper management is primarily a joke. Don't discharge children home because it lowers the census? That's not exactly what the goal should be...personally I thought it was about helping children and families live successfully. No overtime pay-you are allowed to flex off, but how is that possible when you are working 50-70 hours/week and still can't complete the paperwork on time? No family life. High turn-over results in over-worked staff.

review_title: Good place to get experience but get burned out very quickly
job_title: Transitional Living Specialist in Woburn, MA
pros: Lots of support from coworkers.
cons: The job was not the same as what was described to me initially. I worked 50+ hours per week and had no consideration for the work I have done. I felt that my opinion didn't matter as decisions about the young adults I worked with came from supervisors and  the clinical consultant. If you didn't get done that week what they wanted you to get done the week prior, it was always a back and forth between your supervisor and yourself during group supervision as to why it wasn't done that week instead of talking out any situation collaboratively with coworkers in group supervision. There was no room to grow and move up in the company except to become a supervisor or move laterally into an alternative position which were few and far between.  I did not get the training and supervision I deserved to be more successful. Upper management decided to discharge youth before they were ready due to monetary constraints and also accepted youth that were not appropriate for the program itself.

review_title: If you can stick it out...
pros:
Meaningful work
Great organization to be associated with. People are impressed when you say you work there. 
You work with passionate people 
People working in residential programs can advance pretty quickly. Unfortunately this is partly because turnover is so high. But if you love the work and you are good at your job you can use the turnover to your advantage. 
The benefits package is pretty nice.
cons:
You don't make real money until you're way up in the food chain. Until then, you will definitely be overworked and underpaid. 
They always want to add more and more responsibilities to you, but won't adjust your pay or title. I know a LOT of people who have been through that with YV. Of course you have to pay your dues at any job. But YV takes advantage. It seems like instead of hiring the right people at the right salary to handle certain responsibilities they just add those responsibilities to people who are already in place and don't pay them any more.

job_title: Transitional Living Specialist in Nashville, TN
pros: This is the type of job you dream of if you want to help people. You are actually helping kids and families and you can be creative with how you do it. If you are working in the community based-programs, you make your own schedule for the most part so you can grab lunch with your friends or attend a Dr's appointment during your work day if you want, as long as you are getting your work done. The pay is competitive with other companies, and more than most.
cons: There is a lot of paperwork and at least 2 meetings a week. If you are working with a case that can only meet with you at 6:30 pm, then you must meet with them at 6:30 pm. Sometimes that will happen and you can't control it.

review_title: Documented all required information.Informed personnel for an emergency/illness.
pros: I loved working with these children to show them that they were special and important. These children were basically thrown into the system and most of them lived in foster homes and ran away due to bad environments.They had very low self esteem and I felt it was an opportunity for me to help them, no matter how much or how little that I possibly could. This was more than a job for me. I knew that this was a need that desperately needed to be filled by people who wanted these children to have as normal life as possible with optimism as compassion for themselves without regrets for their existence.
cons: Having the ability to communicate with these children to the best of my capabilities and ensuring them of my intentions to listen to them and let them have the positive attention that they deserved no matter of their tragic backgrounds. All in all I wanted them to have some trust in me so they would know that they could allow trust in some people and not be hurt.

job_title: Family Intervention Specialist in Memphis, TN
pros: Work/Life integration and balance, competitive pay, good benefits, collaborative leadership, professional development opportunities, continuous training, and diverse experiences. Highly recommend this position as you can complete school and work while in this position. A lot of people are getting licensed while working this position.
cons: I see a lot of negative reviews about this position. While it can be demanding most weeks are pretty relaxed. Must have good time management skills. Effective communication skills are necessary to discuss progress and where you need support. There is a fair amount of driving, but what makes this job amazing is my leadership team. Spend a lot of time documenting, but it isn't that bad. They really make or break the experience and my clinical team means a lot to me and they always look out for me. I am on the Memphis Anaya/Intercept team and I feel highly trained to some other Specialists in different departments and we will carry regular Intercept and Lifeset cases.

job_title: Family Intervention Specialist in Memphis, TN
pros: Work/Life integration and balance, competitive pay, good benefits, collaborative leadership, professional development opportunities, continuous training, and diverse experiences. Highly recommend this position as you can complete school and work while in this position. A lot of people are getting licensed while working this position.
cons: I see a lot of negative reviews about this position. While it can be demanding most weeks are pretty relaxed. Must have good time management skills. Effective communication skills are necessary to discuss progress and where you need support. There is a fair amount of driving, but what makes this job amazing is my leadership team. Spend a lot of time documenting, but it isn't that bad. They really make or break the experience and my clinical team means a lot to me and they always look out for me. I am on the Memphis Anaya/Intercept team and I feel highly trained to some other Specialists in different departments and we will carry regular Intercept and Lifeset cases.

job_title: Behavioral Intervention Specialist in Arlington, MA
pros: This is a dynamic, challenging position in a rewarding field for a company that really cares about kids and families. Every day is different in this active job, and the nature of the work leads to rich, lasting friendships with colleagues.
cons: This is a nonprofit organization that cares deeply about fulfilling a public need, but at the end of the day, the bottom line is a huge factor in decision making at all levels. Employees, particularly at the lowest level, are encouraged to work long hours for low compensation in challenging conditions, and mid-level managers are frequently tasked with managing crises related to staffing and youth behavior. The regional officers do their best to be sensitive to employee needs, but budget decisions and state regulations at upper levels create obstacles that are ultimately fielded by folks at lower levels.

job_title: MST Family Counselor in Greensboro, NC
pros: Ironically I practically pursued the company to get to hire me, now that I'm here, ehh.  Lots of training, it's a pro but you will get tired of it.  The multi-tiered clinical case reviewing is not as helpful as MST thinks it is but it does make ppl more accountable.
cons: PAPERWORK OVERLOAD!  I actually enjoy the work itself, but my goodness, every ounce of everything you say has to be documented, some of the structural pieces makes you repeat yourself all week, I don't understand why families have to do about 100pages worth of paperwork between pre-admit and admit just ugh!  Driving hasn't killed me yet but I have a newer car and super fuel efficient, I will say the oil changes come a lot quicker than expected so get use to the wear and tear.

job_title: Family Intervetion Specialist in Nashville, TN
pros: Decent Insurance, can have a flexible schedule, pay isn't TOO bad, good co workers, ability to move up if you can stomach it, but you'll just become a cog in the machine with new stressors.
cons: No work Life Balance, On call rotation, the paperwork and weird treatment plan cycle times, being told that this is therapy when in truth this is textbook case management, the case load of 5- 6 families is way too high. For QUALITY care, there needs to be no more than 3. The turn over is high, and people often quit without notice, and you can't even get mad at them for it because deep down you're envious that they had the guts to do that.  You're thrust from training right into the throng of work, which means you are in danger of giving clients subpar "therapy". The job role is unclear as well.

job_title: Behavior Intervention Specialist in Arlington, MA
pros: Good to get your foot in the door & start a job in the mental health field. Friendly staff.
cons:
The management at youth villages under-staffs and doesn't ensure safety to their employees. They are short staffed and it's a dangerous place to work. When a crisis erupts there's barely enough help on deck (or at all for that matter) to help you safely resolve it. Due to their lack of staffing capabilities and having a backup crew they encrourage emoloyees to come in even during terrible conditions. I'm a hard worker and can make it in whenever possible, but they didn't care; they just told you to get there. OSHA and the Dpf of labor should take a look at 1: the working environment and lack of security and 2: the management styles and their entouragement to come in "no matter what"

They focus on the bottom line, and skate by with the bare minimum. I do not feel safe working here.

job_title: Bilingual Family Intervention Specialist in Memphis, TN
pros: Great employee training, good experience if you are looking to advance in the social services field, a lot of room for advancement within the company. They promote from within and offer tuition reimbursement. A lot of opportunity to see a variety of social services settings. Very results driven. Incredible employee benefits. It's a good job if you go in knowing what to expect.
cons: Low starting pay, although that is almost all social work jobs. You will work long hours if you are involved with direct care, to the point that it sometimes feels like you are neglecting your own family to help someone else's. Leadership doesn't always listen to field staff who are directly working with the kids and seems somewhat disconnected from front line staff. Sometimes seems like they either hold onto cases too long or discharge too early from care because they are overly concerned with the census numbers (but that goes back to the disconnected leadership).

pros: The people are nice. I like working with the families. The resources available are useful.
cons: Everything else. They claim to care about their employees but don't. They don't value your time. They don't do anything for extra efforts to complete your work on time. I invest over $700/month just to work. I drove over 3000 miles in my car in less than a month. You need to get your own computer and Internet (which is not reflected in the amount above). Sometimes I work until 3 in the morning, 16+ hour days. Holidays are more of a detriment than a bonus. You end up having the same amount of work in fewer days. Same goes with sick days. They don't care about the clients, they only care about CYA. High turnover also reduces morale. There's a sense of appreciation from your team but not beyond. It's pretty superficial. It's a small company but you never know everyone.

review_title: You accumulate vacation time but don't get to take it.
job_title: Overnight Teacher Counselor in Linden, TN
pros: You really make a difference in the children lives. The children make the job worth having and make you not want to leave.
cons: The management is extremely unprofessional, they push for you to work on your off time and go above and beyond but do not try to help with the stress you endure during work. If you are offered a advancement and don't take it they try to make it so you can't transfer anywhere else by giving bad references and write-ups. Some of the staff is extremely incompetent and they won't be fired the supervisor will just talk about them behind there back and let you deal with the stress and unsafe environment of working with them.  You will accumulate vacation time but the supervisors wont give you vacation time because they don't want to work in your place. No time for sleep and you will want to spend a whole day off just catching up on sleeping.

job_title: Family Intervention Specialist in Boston, MA
pros: Lots of passionate people.  Model sees some positive outcomes.  Large organization with a lot of resources.  Fast-paced.  Quick moves up the organizational ladder.  Typical pay for out of grad school job.  I had some great supervisors who really cared but were also stressed to the gills.
cons: My job expected me to work on call 24 hours a day and put me in dangerous situations.  The supervisors did not support modifying the model when it was clinically appropriate (for instance---encouraged me to try to persuade a family away from hospitalizing their psychotic child as the model tries to avoid hospitalization at all costs).  High level of burn out and fast turnover.  Lots of driving within a catchment which can be huge.

pros: I have worked at Youth Villages now for 7 years.  Youth Villages provides great benefits, and training programs for all levels of employees.   Chief Officers at YV care and listen to staff and implement changes for the better. I spent almost 20 years at a well known for profit organization and I would put our benefits, training, technology and top management staff up against them any day.   Youth Villages cares about their employees always looks for ways to make things better for staff.  I love coming to work everyday.
cons: We do have some staff that like to complain and not be a part of the solution (as with any company or organization).

review_title: Started out great, burnt out quick
job_title: Behavioral Youth Counselor in Arlington, MA
pros: Help out some kids who just need some extra love. See kids go off and do great things. Work with some great people. Occasionally get to have fun with the kids (take them out in the community, play basketball)
cons: Unsupportive leadership team. Almost impossible to take time off.  Required to acquire doctor's notes in order to take sick time. Take overtime but expected to do more. Incredibly low pay for what is expected of you.

job_title: CBHI In Home Specialist in Woburn, MA
pros:
Rewarding work with clients
Great co-workers/ clinician team
flexible hours
lax dress code
cons:
Management 
Inappropriate match up for family needs
Disregard of evidenced based approaches approved by insurance
Tunnel vision on certain approaches with ineffective and inappropriate roll out
Condescending management
complete disregard for what the employee needs to support the family
Horrible work/life balance 
No flexibility with school needs to better oneself
Not enough promotion of self-care leading to high turnover and quick burnout
Not enough training around cultural diversity

job_title: Transitional Living Specialist in Tulsa, OK
pros: They stick true to there mission and the client and families are always first. They encourage bonding between the youth and have company gatherings to build morale. You get to see how your helping someone else's life change for the better or at least encourage thorough processing before taking action. Highly recommend to anyone who is passionate about helping others as everyone there  strongly cares for the clients served.
cons: Most times you work more than 40 hours a week in order to get paperwork completed and families seen as well. Not including the on-call weeks. Boundaries are not clear for some and your expected to do things before you are properly trained in it. Not always the safest neighborhoods and travel during weather. Hard to balance work and life especially if you have small children and is the sole caregiver.

review_title: Not for the Faint of Heart
job_title: In Home Therapist in Boston, MA
pros:
This job has given me so much, in my time at Youth Villages I have been able to work on my clinical skills as well as learn how to manage a realistic paperwork load. Anyone who doesn't expect this level of involvement in the social work field is fooling themselves. Don't be afraid to ask supervisors for what you need, it is a hugely important part of the job! To have a good work/life balance you need to know your own boundaries and you need to not be afraid to say no sometimes! This job can take over your life if you let it. 

In the field experience 
Flexible schedule
Collaborative teams 
Offers LMHC supervision
Challenging cases 
Great benefits
Mileage reimbursement
cons:
Days can be long due to scheduling on the availability of your clients
High turnover rate 
On call system can be a nightmare

pros: Youth Villages is very dedicated to improving the lives of youth and families from every walk of life. They ensure that staff are trained in evidence based practices and this development actually prepare employees for various social service career paths. While at YV I worked in various roles...counselor, manager and director. This was due to my own experience, personal drive and largely b/c of the training and development that was provided to me. The agency has a great culture and there is a lot of support, if you are dedicated to making a difference, changing lives and growing this the company to work for. The bottom line no job is easy but Youth villages really care about kids and b/c of this they will ensure that the staff are properly trained to provide the best service to them.
cons: The company is rather large so it will require skillful networking to build relationships in other departments.

pros: love the families/youth that we work with, love the support from coworkers.  The idea of the work that is being done, is awesome and needed
cons:
Leadership is abusive, absolute bullies. They want everyone to work tons of hours, it doesn't matter if you had 2 days off from vacation, you are still expected to see everyone the same amount of time, work over 40 hours and use your personal time. The families do not get what they need because no one cares from the leadership so we don't grow and are miserable. The outcomes are not long lasting. The specialist now see 5 families instead of 4 .  
The Leadership use bullying as their style of leadership.  They do not care about self care, no one cares about the families, they just pretend to care. 

There is little guidance, there is little or no feedback on treatment plans and then will accuse you of not doing your job. People are blamed if something goes wrong with the families.

pros: The families you serve, and those coworkers who are in it for the right reasons.  If a social worker or counselor is of the mind to climb a corporate ladder, then this is possibly a good fit if you are up for fighting to stay on the island.
cons: Competitive and catty work environment.  Huge surplus of disgruntled present and past employees make it difficult to be taken seriously when you have a hard day or feel abused by the office environment, or want to post your negative review on a blog.  To actually survive past the rollover rate of 6 months will demand a meanness from the employee, which ethically seems like a large character flaw of a work environment for counselors.

review_title: I wouldn't recommend working here in this position.
job_title: Behavioral Youth Counselor in Douglasville, GA
pros: Resume builder for my desired field of work. I can't speak to benefits because I declined them. Some of the people I met were nice.
cons: Supervisors treat employees with extreme disrespect. Scheduling (depending what unit one works on) can be challenging on the body (e.g., our mandatory schedule was to work 40 hours per week , 8 hours each evening Wednesday  - Friday  (3 PM - 11 PM) followed by 16 hour shift on Saturday (7 AM to 11 PM), leaving little time for sleep between Friday night (after work) and Saturday morning's work shift.  The children here can be very aggressive. Much of my time was spent breaking up fights, keeping them from destroying the unit, etc. Very bureaucratic environment. Company does not value it's employees at all.

pros:
Great group of clients and unique experience to help young adults who are aging out of foster care and don't have anyone else in their corner. 
Awesome colleagues
Professional Corporate feel, even though its a non-profit
Competitive Salary for the field
cons:
Insufficient training at time of hire
Lots of turn over among the organization because this type of work has high burn out rates
Not enough paid time off ( would help with burn out if there was)
Suggestions for improvement move slowly because the company is so big and everything must be "approved" 
Catching on the the "YV way"

pros: Overtime was nice, camaraderie among shift members, getting to work with and support kids who were invested. Significant periods of downtime, allowed to read or study during these times. If you were given enough time in a program, you could create structure.
cons: Long, often unpredictable hours, for relatively low wages. if another staff member called into work, which frequently happened, especially on the weekends, you couldn't leave until management found a replacement. Staffing shortages often created potentially unsafe working conditions for you and for the kids. It was very difficult to maintain any sort of work-life balance. After moving sites, there was very little support or consistency in expectations/rules, which made structure very difficult to maintain. Very little opportunity for advancement.

job_title: Teacher Counselor in Fort Mill, SC
pros: Your co-workers are great.  That's about it.
cons:
I am still pretty new to this company, but I have only had one day off since I started working.  They say they give you paid time off, but don't expect to get that time off you request approved.  It's impossible and you have to request it three months in advance.  I work roughly 65-70 hours per week and that's not really by choice.  They also ask you to work night and day shifts, sometimes double shifts, so it's really hard to sleep.  Plus if you work nights and sleep in the day, they will be calling you all day long.  

I was at my last job for six years, but I'm still pretty new here and already looking for a new job.  They treat you like you are disposable.  You're just a warm body to them.  The moral is very low.  I've never worked for a company with so many unhappy employees before.

pros: I have the opportunity to make a positive difference in the lives of children and their families. We each work hard to foster positive changes as we believe everyone deserves a chance to have the best life possible. I appreciate the flexibility allowed to ensure my family is taken care of when challenges arise. I work with great group of people  and appreciate the opportunities for advancement. It is simply rewarding every time a family is successful. It is the best feeling when a child is successful and is given a chance. This is what we do!
cons: This job is simply not for everyone. There are a lot of requirements to ensure success. However, we do whatever it takes. We work hard but take time to play when we can to ensure we give our all to each and every child and family.  The long hours can be taxing but the end results make it all worthwhile.

review_title: Overworked, underpaid, vindictive and at times just evil management.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Lake Oswego, OR
pros: At one point there was a huge family atmosphere here, slowly falling by the wayside, but you make amazing connections with coworkers and the work is rewarding
cons: Incredibly long hours, required not to have a life outside of work, even if it's family responsibilities.  Seriously, you are looked down on and treated poorly if you have children that EVER require your presence.  Spent many years at this company and when YV showed up everything changed.  Upper management is incompetent and will not abide being questioned in any way, even when you are right in the end.  Mean comments, snarky behavior, dirty looks.  They do it all.  Care is compromised as is employee safety quite regularly and the attitude is take it or go somewhere else.  Tons of employee injuries.  Just scary and dangerous overall.  I wouldn't recommend this agency to my worst enemey.

review_title: Long hours, low compensation, zero understanding from upper management - AVOID AT ALL COSTS
job_title: Family Intervention Specialist in Knoxville, TN
pros: Working with families (if that's something that you're interested) in and being able to start in a "counseling" position with only a bachelor's degree.
cons: Long hours, frequently placed in dangerous situations, no support from upper management, crazy caseload, wear and tear on your car from frequent driving. On call 24 hours a day. Having on-call hours during the weekends. Horrible compensation. Working 50+ hours a week and only being paid $26,000 is outrageous. I know this is a social service field but seriously?

pros: Specialized training such as TF-CBT and PSB. High levels of supervision and assistance in licensure. Hish levels of professional development and opportunities for advancement.
cons: Unrealistic agency demands from both DCS and Youth Villages. YV tends to be reactionary instead of proactive. Instead of being an angency of change, it has become a part of the problem. Redundant paperwork, redundant meetings and poor communication between corporate and counsellors.

job_title: Family Intervention Specialist in Chattanooga, TN
pros: Flexible work schedule; you make your schedule for most days which is nice if you want to work early morning hours, mid-day hours or late night hours.  You truly do get to make an impact on families/children.  Mileage checks can be very large which is a nice bonus.
cons: The company's expectations of counselors are very unrealistic.  The company has very unethical practices and do things that are highly illegal.  There is very slim chance to every advance throughout the company especially if you are not an ass-kisser to upper management.  The hours you are required to work are very very long hours and you don't get paid to do documentation/notes from home but will get into trouble if you don't do them when you get home.  You are required to be in a rotating on-call schedule for the weekends and you do not get paid for the work you do during on-call.  You get paid very little for the amount of stress and work you have to do.  Very stressful work environment.

job_title: Overnight Teacher Counselor in Lake Oswego, OR
pros: Co-workers who have stood the test of time...bless you all. The kids...I will remember you all...3 days off. Trust me...you'll need it!
cons: I have just been written up for the first time. I was overheard saying in a private office that I was glad it was shutting down and the next thing you know I am written up for a very common practice. Management is the sole reason this company failed. I saw children come out worse than when they were admitted. it's a shame and shame on those who were part of it...anytime an abused child is treated in a disrespectful manner it only furthers their pain. Youth Villages idea of treatment lacks compassion,  kindness and common courtesy. It does not work.. my focus from this point on is to continue with emotionally disturbed foster children using techniques that will actually help.

review_title: How yv gave me an anxiety disorder
pros: I worked for yv in 2015 at the Portland Oregon facility. With very little training I was thrown into a situation with many violent clients who attacked me everyday. I witnessed my co-workers knocked unconscious, kicked in the face and bitten over 13 times. I would scream for help over the radio and no one would respond. I write this over a year later. I still have nightmares over the experience. I regret working there everyday. The kids were hard. They deserved better than what yv could give them. It's a sad story. How one organization can hurt so many people. So many good people that only wanted to good.
cons: There are so many downsides. Yv did so wrong by me and by the kids who resided there. I hope they understand how many people they hurt and lives they destroyed. They lied to me every chance they got.

job_title: Family Intervention Specialist in Madison, IN
pros:
Making a difference and building a relationship with families, youths, and community members. 

Sometimes the flexible schedule works in your favor and you've got an afternoon or morning free.
cons:
You are literally never off. Even on the weekend when someone else is on call, the families will forget and call you. And when you're on call, you're expected to make calls and sometimes in person visits up to two hours away to check on families. 

And seriously just forget about work/life boundaries. I missed a text message from a family because I was sleeping and got chewed out by my supervisor because I should have woken up for it. I had to go out at 11pm at night at least every week to check on a family and they were an hour away.

pros:
Company is something that one can really get behind.
Great healthcare benefits for an entry level job.
Great coworkers where I worked at (People who don't work well with teams don't last long in this kind of environment)
cons:
Due to the nature of the work there is a lot of mental, emotional, and physical fatigue. You can burn out easily if you don't take care of yourself. There are a lot of people who mean well to try to support staff but a lot of times it is through superficial means such as parties with some snacks and silly games. These are great for building camaraderie but sometimes I feel like some improvements to employee lounges and more would go a long way as well.

Also note that hours can be tough. Depending on the shift you are on you may be working 16 hour shifts on the weekends.

pros:
Company is something that one can really get behind.
Great healthcare benefits for an entry level job.
Great coworkers where I worked at (People who don't work well with teams don't last long in this kind of environment)
cons:
Due to the nature of the work there is a lot of mental, emotional, and physical fatigue. You can burn out easily if you don't take care of yourself. There are a lot of people who mean well to try to support staff but a lot of times it is through superficial means such as parties with some snacks and silly games. These are great for building camaraderie but sometimes I feel like some improvements to employee lounges and more would go a long way as well.

Also note that hours can be tough. Depending on the shift you are on you may be working 16 hour shifts on the weekends.

pros: I have worked for Youth Villages for over 10 years now and absolutely love it.  I was 23 years old when I started working here and was given so many opportunities for growth and experience working in different programs.  I am now the Assistant Director over three community based programs and I have the opportunity to work with a lot staff.  I believe the culture is great, everyone is so supportive of one another, and is extremely dedicated to working hard.  The job is difficult and it is not a good fit for everyone because Youth Villages helps the most challenging troubled youth and families but it is so rewarding.  I feel supported in my journey of growth and development and am so lucky for the opportunity that I have to work for such a great organization.
cons: Working with troubled children and families is not easy and is not a good fit for everyone.

pros: Flexible not a normal desk job
cons: Overworked. Management is aweful. They are all friends so if one is mad they all are. Very redundant.  Horrible office morale. They make you give part of pay check back to them. No support from upper management at all. If you go out on vacation you still have to so all you work because no one will help you or the sup will make the teammates pick up the slack. The emotional stress is through the roof. In Morristown office they go through all of foster care staff every 6 months and in home has changed staff about 3 times in the past year. Senior staff don't bother to learn new staff names. What the point. Any and all concerns and complaints are not taken seriously and reprimand is sure to follow.

pros: Working at YV was a lot of fun, and I could feel good about what I was contributing to on a daily basis. My supervisors and colleagues were supportive!
cons: It's a nonprofit, so there aren't a lot of bells and whistles. In my position, I was able to gain great experience that helped me move forward in my career when I left. There were a couple of difficult people that I had to work with on a regular basis, but that's part of life, and there are difficult people everywhere!

job_title: Family Intervention Specialist in Jasper, IN
pros: The case load is manageable, the co-workers are amazing, and you CANNOT beat the level of support that you receive from all levels of your supervision. There are tons of benefits including tuition reimbursement for continuing education, paid licensure classes and supervision, and it qualifies you to have your student loans forgiven after 10 years. Along with that the mileage is quite a nice check to receive once a month (and it isn't taxed!). Overall for me it is much more than the benefits or the money, this is a company that takes care of it's employees despite being so large!
cons: The hours can be erratic, to say the least. You stay under 40 hours, but it is not reasonable to believe you'll be working 9-5. My hours are generally 11-7.

job_title: Teacher Counselor, Program Manager in Portland, OR
pros: There are some really great and well intentioned people who work here.  Many very dedicated individuals trying to do the best they can for kids living in a tough situation.
cons: Very poor work/life balance.  Staff are routinely overworked and lots of overtime gets mandated.  On top of this, there is not a good system for supervisors and managers to support their teams in the milieu.  They have so much paperwork/tracking to do, they can't spend enough time with their groups and as such are often out of touch and unable to prioritize first tier needs.

review_title: This company is so bad that it won't survive much longer
pros: Camaraderie with coworkers--like soldiers who survive a war together; at times seeing a kid improve; some fun company events
cons: Where to start? Leadership is terrible across the board. They simply don't care about employees at all. Even the new "higher salaries" is a joke. I feel they simply use and abuse the staff. No one ever gets real time off. I was continually forced to come in on my scheduled vacation days and that was never even acknowledged. Staff who don't directly help kids get no respect at all. And the new laptop technology they tout is just a way for them to keep tabs on staff who they believe are cheating them. Even many of the leaders have left as conditions get worse and worse. It's a terrible place to work. Dangerous job with no support.

review_title: Run and DO NOT LOOK BACK
pros: Developing relationships with my families.
cons:
1) No work like balance. You will work over 40 hours per week. No questions
2) You are on-call 24 hours a day for your families. If a child leaves the home at ANY TIME you are expect to go out into the community and search for them. It does not matter if the neighborhood is dangerous. 
3) Documentation is on a cycle time. It must be turned in within 24 hours. 
4) Management is a like college sorority. If you do not fit into the "group" you will be outcast. They will also black ball you.
5) They are not strength focused. If anything goes wrong it is your fault. 
6) Most workers get burned out within 3 months. 

During my three years with YV. I saw over 20 employees leave. OVER 20! Very high turn over rates for a reason.

job_title: Overnight Teacher Counselor in Linden, TN
pros: awesome benefits, part time college and licensure paid for by company, great company to work for if you can deal with the kids (not everyone can)
cons: understaffed, overworked, underpaid, campuses are is in the middle of nowhere and few people want to work an hour from civilization

job_title: Behavioral Youth Counselor in Portland, OR
pros: Shared camaraderie with some of the staff, and the level of enthusiasm for the work is always there.
cons:
Company's turnover rate was nearly 90% with all but one other person who went through NEO the same time leaving. There were over 30 new employees just three months ago. 

There isn't any strong policies to protect or prevent employees from harm. Employees who remain at the organization are REQUIRED by management to take on extra shifts when burnt-out employees leave. Personally I have worked more weeks with over 60 hours than most. This is a serious BOLI violation. 

Employees are also required to spend all "break" and "lunch" times with clients. How is that a break? Honestly you're better off working in the food service industry, at least your physical safety is better off and so is your mental health. FYI pay is $10.50/hour.

pros: Good job working with the youth and their families. Some great employees and overall pretty flexible unless work in the field and programs. The focus on the kids and helping them get better and become productive members of society
cons: Management or lack thereof especially in the Admin area. No way to truly move up unless an officer or director endorses you. Don't go by your work ethic but by the way leadership like you. Have lost a lot of great employees due to this. Very low pay for the jobs due to non profit status

job_title: Family Intervention Specialist in Johnson City, TN
pros: Good money for the field and geographical location. Good benefits. Good clinical experience. Meaningful work.
cons: Four cases is manageable. Five cases gets harder. By six months you will be responsible for carrying six cases and working like a dog. You will have no life outside of work and be stressed out all of the time. They have a clinical supervisor with a bachelors degree who is also unlicensed and supervising masters level clinicians. They say that they will provide supervision for your license, but they don’t.

pros:
Working with the youth
Mileage reimbursement
Health Benefits
cons: Everything. The turnover rate is horrible. Management is very well aware of the issue but has done very little to address it. My manager was rude and inconsiderate. The employees are not respected, rather treated like children. I saw a manager go off on their employee in front of everyone in a very disrespectful manner instead of pulling them to the side. There is no work life balance. You are overworked and underpaid. I was doing the work of a therapist without the proper credentials. They often take in youth who are not appropriate for the program, making client turn over high as well. YV does not care if you have a family of your own. This is job for people straight out of college.

job_title: Family Intervention Specialist in Portland, OR
pros: Great people to collaborate and work with. Freedom to make your own choices. Good Benefits. Sign on bonus. Ability to make fast progress with youth. Flexible schedule.
cons: The expectations of the Family Intervention Specialist are to great for one person to achieve with any longevity in the position. Burnout happens frequently and there is a high turnover of staff.  Systems/program guidelines can create barriers for building rapport with youth.

pros:
Flexible schedule
Mileage checks 
Supportive team members
cons:
Limited work life balance 
Lack of clinical support 
24/7

Please be aware that this job is intense. I found it difficult after awhile to manage my young family and the families I was serving. It became very clear that this would not be a position that would be able to take in consideration that being a parent is important. There were long days and long nights. After awhile I didn't want to see or hear my phone ring.  The on call rotation can be crazy and supporting a family you know nothing about can also be difficult.

pros: I have worked at YV for 15+ years and the number of folks you help here is unparalled at any other social service agency in the state of TN.  The hours are long and the work is, at times,  tiresome but the differences you make with our children and families are totally worth it.  If your calling is to make positive and long lasting changes for families, Youth Villages is the right place for you!
cons: Hours are long and on call is at times stressful, but that would accompany any job in this line of work.   We are compensated well for our efforts and our benefits are good, which offsets any long or stressful weeks.

pros: Incredible bond with co-workers. Feeling supported by same level peers. Working and making an impact with a vulnerable population. Clinical experience and ability to move up in positions. Well known organization.
cons: Upper leadership show very little respect for supervisors and direct care staff. There is a overwhelming sense of entitlement in upper leadership, and unwillingness to admit when wrong has been done. Poor and untimely communication/decision making.

job_title: Director, Leadership Development in Memphis, TN
pros:
- People are fully invested in the mission to help children & families live successfully at all levels of the organization. 

-The company offers world-class training & development to all staff. 

-Tuition & licensure reimbursement 

- Great Benefits (health coverage, holidays, etc.) 

- Family friendly work environment
cons: - Staff that work directly one on one with children and their families may be required to work long hours because the work we do does not fit into a standard 9-5 position.

review_title: Night Monitor Position- Amazing how they take advantage of staff.
pros: I love working with kids and finding different ways to get to them. Barely any pros. This place is a horrible place to work.
cons: The management sucks. After working your shift, they try to make you stay longer to drive kids around, & sometimes very far. Very subtly racist. You can feel the invisible barrier, and you prob won't understand unless you are someone of color. They might not all be like that but that's what's it like at the Germane Lawrence campus.  No Lunch breaks. And they try to guilt you into doing things for no extra pay. Every 15 mins you will be up on your feet doing what they call "wanding".

pros:
-Good co-workers
-Opportunity to engage in meaningful work
-Exciting pace at times
cons:
-Unreasonable work load and staff expectations
-No training
-Extremely high turnover rate leads to unqualified or unworthy individuals to be promoted to supervisory roles
-Management has lead several meetings where they promised to address our concerns that have lead to the high staff turnover, but have not made any changes throughout my time in the organization

pros:
-Good co-workers
-Opportunity to engage in meaningful work
-Exciting pace at times
cons:
-Unreasonable work load and staff expectations
-No training
-Extremely high turnover rate leads to unqualified or unworthy individuals to be promoted to supervisory roles
-Management has lead several meetings where they promised to address our concerns that have lead to the high staff turnover, but have not made any changes throughout my time in the organization

review_title: I stayed way longer than I should have
pros: Growing company, meaningful mission, great people doing the actual work. Upper management makes good money and great benefits. Due to fast national growth, lots of opportunity for advancement on the direct care side.
cons: Plantation mentality, only wants young, inexperienced workers who can be molded to their corporate line. Also, front line workers are expected to work horrendous hours with little to no time off and little pay. Turnover on the front lines is off the chart - at the time I left they were lucky to keep folks for six months.

review_title: Worst Professional Experience of my life
pros: There are no pro's at this place
cons: The coworkers were horrendous. My apartment was burglarized twice by coworkers. If you don't suck up to management or have an inappropriate physical relationship with them, you can expect to get the worst schedule. I literally would not wish this experience on my worst enemy. This was the most unprofessional place I have ever worked. TC's are VERY overworked and no one cares. I reported several instances of unethical abuse that happened in my cottage, and nothing was ever done about it. I wish the news would run a story on the atrocities that occur here. These poor children come to YV to escape abuse and in my experience, they continued to be abused at YV. If you have any morals or integrity, DO NOT work here.

review_title: Great Vision, Great Talk, but this office is too caught up in itself.
job_title: Family Intervention Specialist in Woburn, MA
pros: The Clients and a few of the coworkers
cons: Cliques, Overworked and the only people that give the company high marks are not in the field.  Lot's of promises made to employees and are then redacted.  Promises of support made to clients, but then it falls on the clinicians to follow through with little to no support from the company.  60 hour work weeks are not appropriate when doing clinical work.  Extremely high turnover and very few trained clinicians, including those in supervisory levels.

job_title: Residential Treatment Counselor in Memphis, TN
pros:
- great experience with rapport building, crisis management, and documentation 
- the kids
cons: The staff shows blatant favoritism. They cover up the crimes and wrongdoings of their favorite coworkers and continue to put the children in harm’s way to cover up all of the lies that have been told over the years. There is corruption at all campuses and the children are suffering. Many children are abused and harmed at their facilities. Consistent sexual harassment from other coworkers of the opposite sex. Horrible pay, horrible benefits. Pat, the CEO, is phony and will walk through for photo events but not even speak to the staff or kids. It’s all a big show for the media.

review_title: Do NOT work for Youth Villages
job_title: Primary Services Coordinator in Jackson, MS
pros: I enjoyed some of my co-workers other than that, it is hard to find positives about this place.
cons: I cannot tell you the amount of crazy things I was asked to do with this job. These people have incredibly unrealistic expectations for the employees. The higher-ups are delusional and don't care to know what's really going on at the bottom. I was sent out at 3 am to look for runaways while their parents slept on several different occasions. We were expected to take the kids on to raise ourselves. Do NOT work for this company!!

pros: Great mission.  Wonderful opportunity to help children.  Decent benefits.  Great colleagues.
cons: Some offices have horrible management.  They do not respect their employees, This is a difficult job and the lack of consideration for life balance is awful.  Most of the upper management have not been on the front line for years and the expectations have doubled since they did it. They offer token motivation and have no respect for their employees experience.

pros: Good experience with learning more therapy techniques in the program. Supervisors really knows how to support the team when they need it the most. Easy to take vacation when needed. Valuable work with the families we serve. Tough cases but worth it when therapy is complete. Great work/life balance! Ability to do everything electronic. Paperwork has been cut in half since I first started. Training is extensive. I feel like I have increased my therapeutic skills tremendously!
cons: It is hard work, but it is social work.

review_title: Stay for a year...but then move on.
job_title: Senior In Home Counselor in Chattanooga, TN
pros: I personally enjoyed the amount of knowledge I gained from working with this company. I was able to learn how to document well, handle crisis situatons, and discuss goals I had for the future in the company. This is also one of the rare companies that one could meet the CEO almost twice a year and he praises his employees for their hard work and dedication for children and their families.
cons: This company has a difficult time offering consistent support for employees due to everyone being overwhelmed by paperwork and case loads. The company is not ideal for anyone that's married or in a serious relationship because the company judges their success with families by how little they use the law enforcement or have disruptions, so they do not allow counselors to call the police to assist in crisis situations (ie a client that has runaway from home, become physically aggressive with family, or is homicidal or suicidal). Due to this, counselors are often called by families to unsafe enviornments in the middle of the night with not much support. The company has many redundant meetings (around 6 hours a week to be exact) and it hinders the counselors from doing their jobs effectively. The promotions in the company do not correlate with your education or experience  because someone with a Masters degree and much experience can be supervised by someone with a Bachelor degree just because they have been with the company longer. The company will usually only place 4 clients at a time on a counselor during their first year, but will increase their work load significantly after they have been there over a year; however overtme is not given because it has to be requested ahead of time, but you do not know when a crisis will happen, so you can never get it approved ahead of time!

review_title: Like Cattle to the Slaughter House so I worked at YV
job_title: Bilingual Family Intervention Specialist in Woburn, MA
pros: Compensation was not bad for a first job.  They will promote but do you really want to be the imcompotent supervisor everyone despises.
cons:
I would have to say that I worked myself to the bone.  I worked 60 to 80 hour weeks.  I worked hard and went above and beyond…I won employment awards.  Eventually, I was like a supervisor helping with treatment plans, training and doing other task (not getting paid more though).  I grew as a clinician.  I got accolades from supervisors and others.
