review_title: Depends on Location of Job,Not for long term employment
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Helps some children in need, if staff there for the chilgren and are allowed to do their job.
cons: No communication or consistency among staff/ managemennt.. Pay scale depending on location.Lack of structure and support High staff turnover.

review_title: Dont expect to have a life!! If you have a choice, RUN!!
job_title: Primary Services Coordinator-MYPAC in Blue Springs, MO
pros: I currently work in the in-home mental health program for MS, called MYPAC. Its great working with children and families trying to procide services and support outside of a facility. You truly get to meet the families where they are.
cons: Burn out is quick. The turn over rate is constant due to unrealistic expectations such as case load and documentation. Average daily driving is between 100 miles-300 miles. On average most staff spends all day seeing clients and then the expectation is that you return home and stay up until midnight completing paperwork. There is a 24hr documentation deadline. They are quick to write you up or threaten you with further limitations that will only make the job harder. There is no real supervisory or management support for staff. There are also major issues related to a lack of concern for staff safety. They will literally order staff to go to homes alone where there are guns, knives and individuals with a history of violence and drug use. They are constantly adding new documentation that does nothing to help the individuals we serve but adds to staff stress levels. The actual caseloads are unrealistic. When being hired your are told 6-8 cases but in reality it is 10-12. They truly just dont care about the well-being of their staff, which is why the turnover rate is so high. Since I began working for YV, sixteen people have left. I have been with the company two years. There are those in management that have no people skills whatsoever. At times, they will literally not even deign to speak to staff when they walk by. If you are sick, they wont care and will continue to call you and send texts and emails about deadlines even if you are off of work. They will make you go to homes where people are sick and contagious and where there may be infestations and unsanitary conditions. Also, care coordinators are blamed for everything, even when clinical staff fail to do there jobs and dont provide therapy as outlined. Even when there are reports of therapist not seing clients, mistreating clients and just lying about providing therapy, YV does nothing. They care more about billing than they so about the actual services being provided. Some children end up worse than they were when they started services due to poorly trained, unprofessional and uneducated therapists.

review_title: RUN AS FAST AS YOU CAN!!
pros: The children that you work with and the colleagues/coworkers on your team who know EXACTLY what you're going through are the best parts of this job.
cons:
Where do I begin? This is a TERRIBLE place to work. Upper management couldn't care less about their staff. They don't care about you being sick, whether or not there's a holiday, whether you go on vacation...NOTHING. All they care about is that you get all of your hours in (even if it's a short week) and that you complete the ginormous amount of documentation in an unrealistic timeframe-under any means necessary. I read the negative reviews on line before accepting this job, and accepted it anyway. I was desperate. But even desperation will not keep me here. After less than 4 months, I am leaving. I would advise ANYONE considering working here to reconsider. If having a life outside of work, and having peace of mind are important to you- DO NOT WORK HERE. If being supported by your supervisor, being taken seriously by upper management, and being compensated fairly for your work are important to you- DO NOT WORK HERE. The pay is miserable. The wear and tear and mileage put on your car is absurd. 
Listen, this is literally the worst place I have ever worked for in my entire life. I've been out of graduate school, have held my degree, and have been working in the field for almost a decade, and I can honestly say that I'd rather work as a janitor in a jail (no offense to janitors who work in jails; I'm sure you all are treated WAY better, and are WAY happier with what you do than the employees at YV) than work for Youth Villages. OVER. IT.

review_title: Great coworkers, out of touch leadership
job_title: Life Skills Specialist in Wichita, KS
pros: Working with youth aging out of foster care and other higher levels of care that many times do not have support. I also loved the bond I had with my coworkers.
cons: Leadership patronized staff in team meetings. The company lacks the ability to support their employees of color and engage in clique behaviors.

review_title: Company needs to make major changes in their treatment of employees
job_title: Family Intervention Specialist in Park City, KS
pros:
Amazing *stated* work mission and values (This is why I wanted to work for the company). 
Great relationships with coworkers and many opportunities to collaborate with other service providers.
cons:
Horrible at following through with mission and values. Work-life balance is non-existent and they blame you if you cannot make it better. Pay is minimal and raises are few and far between. Everyone is over worked and miserable, and these are your friends that you want to help but don't have time to help. Twelve hour days and no ability to get ahead even for the most organized person. The people that stick around tend to be ones that owe the company due to further pursuit in education or retirement savings. They immorally (decision has to be made in front of coworkers in effort to get jeans days) guilt you into giving a percentage of your already tiny salary back to the company. Success means a kid that did not get in trouble, not actual turn-arounds because you didn't have enough time with families to actually make these changes (three months max to make a long term impact with families who don't even want you around half the time). Parents are guilted into receiving your help by telling them a report to CPS will be made if they do not follow through with services. 
Also, I remember reading these reviews and thinking people were crazy and maybe they were the problem. I hope future readers do not make that same decision.

pros: The work is meaningful and impactful. The team is cohesive, supportive and friendly. Some of the management is cool.
cons:
-Bad benefits
   1. Don’t take effect until after 90 days
        A. No medications or Doctor Visits will be covered within 90 days
   2. Employee 6% goes into a private fund that isn’t vested for 5 or more years if you make it
    3. You get to earn 10 days of vacation a year that go away at the end of the year.
         A. They don’t role over and you can’t use them unless you earn them
- High Turn Over
   1. Increased burn out
   2. You have to cover extra shifts with no extra pay or benefits 
        A. Enjoy working 50 hours a week and getting paid the same as 40
- Trouble with work life balance.
   1. You need to attend mandatory meetings on your days off 
   2. The meetings are in the middle of they day and they are difficult to plan around if you want to enjoy a day at the beach, Mt. Hood, or other self-care
- Management is just as burned out as you are 
- HR department is rude, slow, and unreliable
   1. Good luck applying for benefits. If they haven’t messed up your health insurance application, the odds are is something is wrong...
    2. Organize all of your own paperwork and keep track of everything
- Unreliable work conditions
   1. You will spend more time yelling at your slow barely functioning computer that like won’t load
    2. Don’t get me started on the souls sucking work conditions of the office. You’ll find out for yourself
- Prepare to cry a lot... A lot... a lot. 
   1. Likely you will have to cancel on family events because you have to working over your shift
   2. Being so frustrated with work will strain work life balance and relationships
- Pay is terrible

review_title: The work our specialsits do is amazing!
pros: Great benefits; provides multiple career paths for those wishing to grow in the field; the majority of the senior managers have worked in direct care jobs and understand the complexity and challenges of the positions
cons: Work life balance can be a challenge

pros: You will have an opportunity of a lifetime to work with some of the most challenging students. You could make a short-term difference in the lives of students.  YV has nice facilities with beautiful landscaping to present a tranquil environment to the visitors and prospective employees....
cons: Too many cons. (Read ALL of these reviews carefully. You will see a number of favorable reviews at the beginning.  Keep reading and you will see a lot more unfavorable reviews of YV out of 200+ reviews.  Note a high turnover rate among teachers, counselors and other staff at YV. ) The working conditions are deplorable. If you think small classroom size is a plus, think again... (Too much to say here on that issue.)  Management lies to you, saying one thing and doing another.  Teachers and counselors can expect to make $10K less than another school setting and the work is year-round!  The more work you do, the more work that they expect you to do.  At YV, you may feel as though you are actually paying the company to work there.  At YV, you will learn soon enough of  a branded and identured servant mentality.... You'll also be asked  to make a contribution from your paycheck back to YV.  I can't enumerate all the cons.  If you are conned into working at YV, you cannot say that you were not warned....

pros: There is nothing good about this company. Even if you think helping kids will be rewarding, trust that this is not the route. Find another way to help kids or another way to work in a psychology field.
cons:
I was told in my interview that no matter what schedule I am assigned I will have a 16 hour shift every week. I asked what kind of lunch break system is in place for such a long day? He answered two hour lunches. NOT TRUE. You will get zero lunches everyday and even on a 16 hour day! You are expected to eat the food on campus with the kids while watching the kids and waiting on them. The food is worse than what I assume prison food is like. Unhealthy and tastes terrible. If you walk past the fans blowing hot air from the kitchen outside you will catch a scent of something indescribable. 

My first day after training I walked into a room of kids completely unattended. 30 minutes later a kid came out of a holding room ALONE. While I was shadowing I was left with a coworker who was relatively new and he fell asleep. Everything the guy I was shadowing told me to do management would come around and tell me not to do. They would not follow up with an alternative suggestion of what is allowed either. 

Management on the floor had a horrible attitude with me from day one. The only thing I could deduct was that he was mad he didn't interview me? He had no other reason to hate me from the moment he laid eyes on me. If it wasn't related to not interviewing then it was either gender or race related? 

They ask you to come in hours before your shift for a meeting and then afterwards just hang out before your shift starts for two hours not like 10 minutes. 

They hire in large batches and constantly ask if you are going to stay. They all know the company is horrid and are literally expecting half the large new hire group to be gone in months. 

The mental health patients are not the problem. It's management. It's low pay. It's crappy hours and demanding expectations. 

Seriously you will have 16 hour shifts with no breaks. Zero. 

Do not apply to this company.

pros: The only pro at this agency and in my position was changing children's lives by providing them with the life skills to become independent young adults.
cons:
Management treat you unprofessionally. It's evident they don't trust their workers and micro manages to the point They will question about a gap in your schedule as though you aren't  traveling from one client to another during the peak traffic times in Charlotte. Their only concern is money!!!!! They don't care about their employees nor do I believe they truly care about the youth that were being served since they admitted inappropriate youth who would of benefited in services that were more suitable for their needs. There is a high turn over rate which is a reflection of the incompetent leadership that does not know how to manage or lead. Any concerns  brought to management are swept under the rug. They do not support their staff. Very unhealthy work environment.  I've been in this field for 10 years and I've never experienced this amount of incompetence in leadership roles! In all my years this is by far the worst agency I have EVER worked for! I wish I knew about GlassDoor before I accepted their offer because the reviews don't lie! There's so many layers of dysfunction, from the head to the tail and going to HR with concerns don't bring about change either! 
Pay=HORRIBLE! I was making what I made 10 years ago straight out of college, left and my experience and education was rocognize by the right agency! They have high demanding timelines/deadlines, no work life balance and after being exhausted from it all with little pay don't you look for any "real" support from your supervisor!
This agency needs a restart, shift all management out and bring in people that can truly manage.

job_title: Behavior Youth Counselor in Memphis, TN
pros: Making a difference in children's lives
cons: Lack of teamwork, micromanaged, incompetent managers, high turnover rate, unprofessional staff, excessive paperwork, switch and bait pay, staff lack of concern and compassion for the youth/mistreatment (poor sweet peas) Don't work at Youth Villages new graduates you will regret it! The only people writing good reviews is their Youth Villages Staff. Don't believe the hype!!!!

job_title: Foster Parenting Provider in Johnson City, TN
pros: It was all for the children, so they say but lying to children constantly, mean to the kids, they as well put families in danger with level 4 kids that are not suppose to be in your home
cons: Horrible company to work for habitual liars, 0 confidentiality, no privacy, don't care about there kids. Won't help the parents for appointments. Place children in your home in emergency then fail to come back to get the kids lying claiming it was a placement

pros: Great place to get experience, great benefits. Youth village needs to encourage ongoing Training and help motivated workers move up in the company.
cons: Rotating schedule required. It's hard to work rotating shifts and have a normal life long term. Encourage staff with praise helps too!

job_title: Bahavioral Youth Counselor in Arlington, MA
pros: Flexible Hours, Free food, Feels good to help teens, Teamwork, Great upper management, Frequent workshops and trainings, Meetings, Classroom experience.
cons: Teenagers are abusive, Must deal with the teens that hate you, clients lash out at staff and peers, lack of discipline for employees, lack of staffing

review_title: its tough but can be gratifying experience
job_title: Behavioral Youth Counselor (TC) in Douglasville, GA
pros: when the kids behave the days can be fun
cons: when the kids miss behave prepare to be spat on, cussed at, kicked, hit, etc etc etc all the horrible things. loads of paper work, and you have to work a 16 hour shift atleast once a week

review_title: I believe in Youth Villages strong mission to help children and families succeed. I love the company culture!
job_title: MST Family Counselor in Asheville, NC
pros: amazing support, great resources, the company cares about their employees, good benefits, great growth experiences.
cons: tons of paperwork, can be difficult to manage home-work balance, incredibly emotionally tolling at times, not great pay

review_title: Wouldn't Wish This Job On Anyone
job_title: Overnight Teacher Counselor in Arlington, TN
pros: The benefits are alright. And you do end up treating your team like family. Hopefully you're able to make a small difference in a child's life.
cons: Exhausting work. 60-hour work week. No real time to breathe. High Stress levels. Physical danger (possibility of being bitten, scratched, stabbed, etc.). No employee appreciation. No raises even after working a position for several years.

review_title: One of the worst employment experiences ever!
job_title: Family Intervention Specialist in Atlanta, GA
pros:
Working from home.
Working with my families
I met and worked with some amazing people.
cons: Everything else. The expectations placed on Family Intervention Specialists are unreasonable and overwhelming and the pay is down right disgraceful. The Atlanta Office is not able to keep specialists for over a year, most leave in less than that time because it is such a horrible place to work.

review_title: Great place to make a difference for children and families
pros:
Very supportive co-workers. Team approach.
Committed to using the most effective approaches to helping children and families with the most difficult issues.
Good benefits, tuition reimbursement for extra education, support for licensure.
cons:
It's hard work helping really challenging kids and families.
The jobs aren't easy, but there are great emotional rewards and lots of team support.

pros: The population you work with is awesome and the best part of the job. The YVLifeset team is excellent too.
cons: The company does not adequately train its employees and puts them in the fire way before they should be in the field. The company can also do better to educate the workers of resources in the area.

review_title: Good people - demanding work for so so $
pros: The co-workers and clients are wonderful!  The Asheville office tries to provide work/home balance
cons: Very high expectations and challenging work.  Pay is good for people right out of school but not worth it if you have years of experience. Lots of driving and long days.

pros: Watching the children change from good to bad. Seeing that you make a difference with the children.
cons: The staff are like a bunch of high school kids. A lot of gossiping, and backstabbing. The pay sucks and the hours are horrible. 16 hour shifts on the weekends.

job_title: Mental Health Counselor in Biloxi, MS
pros: Pay and benefits are fair. You will get great exposure to community based social services. The best part of the job is the kids.
cons: Lots of paper work, difficult to mange personal life, dangerous at time, if your manager is bad, you will be miserable. The culture is cold and unapproachable.

pros:
Some of the kids really are a pleasure to work.  Easy to move into leadership. 
Great way to network.
Some of leadership offer great mentorship and training.
cons:
Under paid/over worked. 
Feeling unvalued/unsupported.
Dealing with the politics of leadership.
Long days with no scheduled breaks.

pros: Can set own hours, insurance okay, great connection with families.
cons: Too much emphasis on hours, poor pay...too low for the work, local management is out of touch with reality.

pros:
Youth Villages has a commitment to providing world-class training programs to their employees.  The staff development is very personal and directed toward success and leadership! 

The employee benefits are amazing and competitive to some major international organizations. 

The organization has a very clear mission and works to ensure that staff stay focused on children and families.
cons: The mental health industry has a history of high turn over.

pros: It was easy to move up if you are always on top of your paperwork and be a positive person, while at work anyways.
cons: Very high demand of job responsibilities. Doesn't really care about your work/life balance. For the amount of hours I was working and being on-call over the weekends, I wasn't paid enough. Not much support from my regional manager either.

job_title: Family Intervention Specialist in Lakeland, FL
pros: I can't say nothing good about youth villages. I would never work for youth villages again. Worse non profit there is.
cons: That I can think of there's nothing but challenges from the moment you start working for youth villages you encounter challenges.

review_title: Youth Villages is as awesome place to work!
pros: Youth villages provides support and training necessary for the job.  We do what we say we do and love it!
cons: You don't have a lot of time for yourself at certian times, but thre is also flexibility available to staff.

review_title: Youth Villages is as awesome place to work!
pros: Youth villages provides support and training necessary for the job.  We do what we say we do and love it!
cons: You don't have a lot of time for yourself at certian times, but thre is also flexibility available to staff.

review_title: Youth Villages has great promotion opportunities
pros: Ability to be promoted quickly along with leadership development opportunities. Supportive management. Health care benefits.
cons: Salary pay (40 hours a week) with longer than average work weeks (50+ hours a week). Quick turnover rate. Documentation, documentation, documentation.

job_title: Overnight Teacher Counselor in Memphis, TN
pros: The sad part about this is that there aren't any pros. The check would have to be the only pro.
cons: The leadership cares about the leadership. It's a popularity vote when it comes to promotions and quarterly awards. If you are applying for the Teacher Counselor position look for another job now. You do not get paid enough for the work they have you doing.

job_title: Foster Care Counselor in Morristown, TN
